(42)

A.  Acute Subpopulation - 525
There are an average of more than five hundred and twenty-
five new admissions to the Hospital each year who have never
been previously admitted to a mental hospital.  Alternatively,
a total of 32 persons in the Hospital on September 17, 1977
were identified on the assessment survey as either acute or
adolescent with not more than one previous admission, and
t
V hospitalized for less than three months.  Similarly, there
were 29 persons with no previous admissions.  Given the
average length of stay at the Hospital for this subpopulation
of approximately 20 days, these persons represent an acute
population of approximately 550 (29 x 18 - 532; 32 x 18 - 576)
B.  Recidivist Subpopulation - 1076
In order to determine the unduplicated count of persons
admitted to the Hospital over a two year period who had pre-
viously been hospitalized, an extensive review of Hospital
records was undertaken.  This review included examining the
admission history of every person admitted during the six
month period from October 1, 1977 - March 31, 1978.  This
individual analysis allows for an exact determination of the
number and frequency of persons entering the Hospital in a
given time period, in addition to precisely identifying who
those persons are and the source of their referral.
On the basis of this data (see especially Appendix C,
Tables 1 to 3), a total of 1300 annual admissions to the
(43)

Hospital were identified, 736 of which were readmissions.
When this figure was adjusted for repeated readmissions of
the same client, there were 680 unduplicated individuals
identified for a single year.  In order to determine for
a 2 year planning period how many unduplicated recidivist
clients would re-enter the Hospital, a number of data-
based assumptions were made (see Appendix C, Table 4).
Basically, four'separate recidivist subgroups were identified:
Group A:  Consisting of 46 persons, each of whom are
readmitted two to three times each year, and
4 to 6 times over a two year planning period;
Group B:  Consisting of 318 persons, each of whom are
readmitted once each year, and twice over a
two year planning period;
Group C:  Consisting of 121 persons, each of whom are
readmitted about every 18 months, 80_ of whom
could be expected to show up within a single
year, and all of whom could be expected to
ii
show up at least once during the two year
planning period, and;
Group D:  Consisting of 590 persons, each of whom are
readmitted about every 30 months, 236 of
whom could be expected to show up within a
single year, and 472 of whom could be expected
(44)

to show up at least once during the two year
planning period.
Thus, for a one year planning period we would expect 680
unduplicated clients  (46 +318 + 80 + 236) in the
recidivist subpopulation.  For a two year planning period
there would be 957 unduplicated recidivist clients (46 + 318 +
121 + 472*) admitted to the Hospital.
In addition to this total, there are 119 other clients
released form the Hospital on an indefinite visit status,
who returned to the Hospital one or more times during the
year (See Appendix C, Table 3).  Although pursuant to
Department procedures these persons are not formally re-
admitted, they clearly must be considered as part of the
recidivist subpopulation for planning purposes.  Thus this
methodology suggests the total unduplicated recidivist
subpopulation that will be admitted to the Hospital in a
two year period is 1076 persons (957 + 119).
C.  Long-Term Subpopulation - 362
A total of 362 persons at the Hospital on September 17,
1977 had been there longer than three months.  Of this
group more than three hundred had been hospitalized for
more than a year.

D.  Nursing Home Discharged Subpopulation - 172
As of June 30, 1977 there were 178 persons on convalescen

Alternatively a total of 172 persons were discharged from the
Hospital to either a nursing home, rest home, or boarding
home during FY 1977.  Given the exceedingly low readmission

rate from nursing and rest homes, there is little likelihood
this subpopulation is included in the recidivist subpopula-

discharged to nursing or rest homes between 1969 and 1977; of
this number 1240 left between 1969 and 1974.  Thus in years
1975 to 1977, slightly more than 200 persons per year were
discharged to these type of facilities, with only a slight
risk of their returning to the Hospital (1980 --1240).
E.  At Risk Subpopulation - 3588
Based on an October 1977 Department inventory of all
community facilities in Region I, there are 3588 persons
presently being served that were identified as being at
risk of hospitalization in the absence of these programs.
'. t
Although it is difficult to determine with precision the
size of this group, it is clear that existing community
mental health services presently being used by this subpopu-
lation should be maintained at their current levels and not
be considered available to other persons not presently
(46)

receiving such services.  Any decrease or dilution of these
services for this subpopulation would create a substantial
risk that members of this group would be hospitalized.
However, Department staff should retain the discretion to
decide whether a given program is operating below capacity
and is therefore able to serve additional clients without
decreasing existing services to, or creating a risk of
hospitalization for, this subpopulation.  Given these
'•4
programmatic principles, the calculation of this subpopula-
tion represents the best available figure and is supported
by recently collected information in the Region.
Combining these subpopulations, the community mental health system
should be designed to serve 2135 persons through a variety of
programs and residences.  While some portion of this, population,
particularly the long-term and discharged subpopulation (C and D),
may require continuous residential services and programming, a
substantial percent of this group, especially the acute sub-

time.  Moreover, the subpopulation of persons never hospitalized
but at risk of institutionalization (E) should be considered to
be receiving appropriate services at the present time, provided
none of these services are reduced or otherwise altered.  By
grouping each subpopulation into homogeneous clusters, it is

COMMUNITY-BASED RESIDENTIAL SERVICES
FOR MENTAL HEALTH CLIENTS
I.  INTRODUCTION
l\
The following program descriptions, compositions and cost breakdowns are
meant to serve as a guideline for regional and area planning in the development
of community residential alternative programs. The matching of client and
residential alternatives as described for each program is based on the Region
I Client Evaluation Survey.  Approaches to staffing and start up program
costs will require modification depending on such factors as the support
services provided, client level of functioning, location of the facility
and condition of the building.
Program Considerations
An underlying principle in the development of program models should be the
maximizing of individual client growth and the development of individualized
service plans to assist and teach clients to live as normal a 1ife as possible
in the mainstream of the community.  This can be facilitated by incorporating
the developmental model when designing  Individual Service Plans, recognizing
the capability of each person to learn, grow and develop, no matter how severely
disabled.
Many clients in need of a community residential  placement require assistance in
gaining self-help skills, socialization skills, and use of community resources.
For some clients training may be quite basic; for others, more sophisticated,
depending on the individual  level of functioning upon entry into the community
program.  In addition, some clients may require an individualized program to
eliminate problemmatic behaviors and/or supervision of basic physical care needs.
The following programs describe staffing and cost figures for either eight bed
residences or 4 bed apartments.  Although each apartment is described for a
maximum of four persons, two separate apartments might be clustered together
in one large building or adjacent buildings.  In no event, however, should
programs be located in such geographical  proximity as to create an undue
concentration of clients in one area or neighborhood.
Many of the attached program descriptions include the alternative of operating
programs in either houses or apartments.  As many programs can be implemented
in either type of housing, facility decisions should be based on the programmatic
flexibility as well as on the barriers to implementation and operation presented  >
by each type of facility.  These may include the relative social advantages of
a small apartment for four persons over a larger home for eight residents; tMe
ability to design and implement service plans on a more individualized basis
in smaller settings; the reality that small apartments are more normative than
larger homes; considerations of the types of housing available in an area; the
availability of start-up monies (minimal  for an apartment program which  rec!u1[e*  '
 tJ
no mortgage); cost of alternative staffing requirements (often higher in aoart^e  .,;
than in homes); renovation or time delays caused by the need to meet tne 5ta:3
Building Code for Group Residences; and issues related to community acceptance
and integration and local zoning ordinances.

Finally, some of the residential alternatives are described as specialized
programs for persons with severe behavioral  problems and/or physical care
needs.  Staffing in these programs has been designed to provide the
additional coverage required by the added program responsibilities.
Programmatically, however, it is important for any one facility to have a
mixed population with regard to level of severity of disability, as an
important aspect of residential  programming  is peer role modeling, inter-
action and support.  It is recommended that no more than half the residents
in any specialized program require intensive behavioral  intervention or
physical care.  Special subpopulations, such as programs for adolescents,
may require alternative staffing configurations.  With some modifications,
however, the range of specialized programming needs should fit within the
alternative residential  programs described herein.
Satellite Model of Organizing Network of Community Residential  Services
When planning an area network of community residential  programs one concept
to consider is the Satellite Model of Organizational  structure.  This consists
of a core residential unit which, in addition to providing services and training
to clients who live there, also provides managerial  support and program
coordination for each program in the area's network of residential  services.
Professional  staff as needed by the residential  network are maintained by the
unit and are responsible for providing programmatic coordination and management
for clients within the network.  Some clients receiving services in the
satellite netowrk may never live in the core unit itself but may move into a
satellite setting directly.  Others may live in the core unit during an
evaluation period, so that an individual  service plan may be developed and
appropriate satellite program identified.  Some clients may come to the core
unit intermittently for respite or emergency care.  Satellite programs may ii
consist of specialized group home or apartment programs, specialized  home
care and support services to clients residing in non-OMH provided or funded
housing (see following descriptions).  Utilization of this model'would
necessitate modification of the enclosed program and staffing descriptions
to accommodate a centralized and consolidated administrative and program
coordination.
Staffing Considerations
Full time staff positions are based on a non-residential  forty hour week rather

than a live-in staff approach.  Programs utilizing live-in staff will  require
modification of the staffing pattern described here.  The annual  salary for mental
health workers is estimated at $9500 with the recommendation that each program
establish two levels of salary, with entry level workers without experience
in community mental  health work (MHW I) beginning at S3500  and those with
greater expertise and/or experience (MHW II) beginning at $10,500.

In addition, it is important that new staff participate in a comprehensive
training program designed to orient them to the larger community mental  health
system, other generic community  services, the goals, objectives and behavioral
techniques of the particular residential  program and a range of skills necessary
to :neet client needs.

On the enclosed charts the nubmer of positions indicated  in the "Direct Care
Personnel" column reflect the number of persons on duty on a particular shift.
The Full Time Equivalent  (F.T.E.) column  indicates the number of forty hour
week positions necessary to provide the coverage.  The "Cover Factor" column
reflects staff necessary to cover vacation and sick leave time.  Recommended
staffing patterns should be viewed from the standpoint of overall  need rather
than rigid adherence to shift.  For example, if a director is at a residence
at scheduled times during the day shift she/he may be able to provide the
minimal coverage required when the majority of clients are engaging  in day
activities outside the home.  It might then be advantageous for some of the
day shift mental health- workers1 hours to be reassigned to the evening shift
when more clients are in the residence.  Additionally, it may be important
to staff understanding of client functioning,inter-staff communication and
program implementation for staff to rotate shifts so that all staff have the
opportunity to be with clients engaging in a variety of daily living and
social  experiences.  Actual  staff scheduling should also include time for all
staff to meet weekly to discuss general  concerns of the program and  individual
client progress, as well as a time for house meetings with all staff and
residents  present.
Staffing  for each program with a minimum of eight clients includes a half
time Oirector/Administrator.  Responsibilities of this position should  include
hiring and supervising direct care staff, coordinating and managing the
residential  aspect of the Individual  Service Plans (ISP), arranging for
support services as needed, facilitating the use of generic community  services,
representing the program in community  relation efforts, providing or arranging
for pre-service and in-service training of direct care staff, managing the
fiscal aspects of the operation and maintaining data as required.  Organizational
structure and staff composition of the residential  program will affect the
responsibilities and time needed for "Oirector/Administrator" duties.  For
example, an agency operating more than one residential  program may require a
full time director  with funding partially provided by each program.  A small
agency operating a single program may want to combine the half-time director
and float time into one position to include both direct care and  administrative
duties and/or may require night staff to handle a portion of the paper
administrative duties such as completion of statistical  reports, etc.
The duties of mental  health workers  include assisting and teaching clients
in learning to live independently, providing counselling and support to clients
as necessary, implementing  the program's goals and responsibilities and  sharing
with the director and other staff the daily operational  tasks of the residence.
Weekday staff are expected to facilitate clients' involvement  in non-residential
programs,activities  and employment, but must be available to clients who, for
whatever reason, do not participate  in such activities.
Budget  Considerations
When calculating the amount cf DMH resources needed for operating expenses, c
income should be deducted  from the total  cost.  Many clients are eligible for
Supplementary Security  Income (S.S.I.) which  is presently 5215.93 per month.
Subtract the amount the client keeps for personal  needs.  Multiply the remainder
by 12 (months).  Reduce this figure by 5% as most facilities average a 5% vacancy
rate over a year's time.  This will  provide you with an estimated  non-OMH house
income.

Provider Considerations
It is generally beneficial  for providers of these programs to be private,
non-profit organizations experienced in operating residences for mentally
disabled clients.  Such providers should have the professional  skills necessary
to design, establish and coordinate quality programs, including the ability
to recruit and train dedicated staff.  They should also possess the
administrative capability and flexibility to manage such programs and
integrate their goals with the larger community alternative system.  To the
extent that small, inexperienced private corporations or public agencies
are used as providers, some modification of these program models may be
necessary to account for the lack of flexibility or other resultant constraints.
Providers also have the flexibility to rent or purchase homes or apartments
as well as the discretion to combine rent, maintenance and some insurance costs
to cover variable rental prices.

III.  START-UP COSTS
Start-Up Costs will vary considerably depending on such factors as
location and condition of facility, whether facility is to be purchased or
rented; whether there are legal complications; the particular building code
specifications to be met, etc.
a.  House Purhcase/Oown Payment:  Conventional mortgages from banks
usually require a 20% down payment.  Thus a $15,000 down payment
-t
would be sufficient to obtain a $75,000 conventional mortgage.
With liberal bank and/or employment of a state/federal mortgage
assistance/guarantee program this amount could vary.
b.  Legal Services:  Generally such services might include title
transfer, zoning advice and legal counseling.  In some instances,
these services might be obtained on a pro bona basis, in which
case there would be no cost.
c.  Real Estate Taxes:  This varies depending on the time of year the
property is purchased.  If the sale is closed in January, taxes
for the entire year must be paid before an exception is granted.
Conversely, if the closing occurs in December, little or no taxes
need be paid.  To date no way has been found to obtain an.
exemption on the first year's taxes short of a legislative act.
d.  Meeting Building Code Specifications:  These requirements include
total smoke and heat detector systems (approximately $5000) and
special fire resistant paint.  Depending on the structure, other
expenses could include widening stairs, adding rear fire escapes,
changing the direction for opening doors, adding fire doors,
installing emergency lighting, etc.
e.  Staff:  Prior to beginning program operation staff must be available
to write proposals, perform need studies, make referral contacts,
hire and train staff, purchase supplies and equipment, deal with
banks, lawyers, contractors, etc.
I
f.  Contingency Fund:  Clients generally move into a new residence a few
at a time over the first few months of operation.  Ouring tnis rime
the majority of expenses are fixed costs that have to be met, in spite
of a lower income from client fees.
g.  Staff Training:  New staff should participate in a comprehensive training
program prior to beginning to work with clients.  Ongoing training should
be provided through consultation funds.

INTRODUCTION
A.  The  Program Models
The program models  described  herein  are  designed  to  provide  mentally
disabled  persons  living  in  the  community with  those  treatment  and  support
services  appropriate  to  their  neeas.  Taken  together,  they  represent  a
continuum  of  programs  that  vary  in  structure  and  intensity  but which
should  enable  clients  to  progress  towards  independent,  productive  lives
in  the  community.  Seme programs  are  primarily  clinical  and offer  a  range
of  treatment  modalities  in  a  radically  oriented  environment;  some  ire
distinctively  nonclinical  and  provide  training  in  various  social,  physical,
vocational,  and  educational  skills  to  assist  clients  in  gaining  such  in-
dependence;  and  finally  others  are  chiefly  supportive,  giving  clients
help,  when  necessary,  in  responding  to  the  demands  of  community  living.
Although  available  to  all  mentally  disabled  persons  Iving  in  the com-
munity,  these  models  are  principally  intended  to  complement  ccrmiunity
residential  alternatives  yj  serving  the  nonresidential  program needs  of
clients  living  in  those  settings.  It  is  the  expectation  that  such  clients
will  participate  in  these  nonresidential  programs  or  other  activities
such  as  employment  or  schooling  five  days  per  week.  Thus  these  programs
are  but  one  piece  of  a comprehensive  network  of  a  conmunity  mental  health
system.

B.  Population to Be Served
It is recognized that some of the treatment and support services
described in the attached models are presently being offered in some form,
although there is a considerable variance between Areas.  Moreover,
certain  nonresidential services such as prescreening, crisis, interven-
tion, and community service coordination are not available anywhere in
the Region.  These program models are designed to supplement existing
services in order to meet the needs of persons who are or may be hospital-
ized due to the inadequacy or total unavailability of appropriate community
treatment and support programs.  Based on a thorough review of data
supplied by the Northampton State Hospital, the Regional Office, and the
client assessment survey, this population includes approximately 2100
mentally disabled persons in Region 1.  (See Analysis of Population in
Region 1.)  In addition, there are approximately 4000 other persons now
receiving partially adequate mental health services from existing programs
which are essential in preventing their hospitalization.  For purposes
of the planning process, it is assumed that the attached models must be
integrated with existing Area programs in a manner that does not decrease
or dilute the services presently being provided to persons Irving in the
community.
C.  Staffing and Costs

The attached models include only a staffing pattern and projection
of costs.  Staffing is in terms of full time equivalents (FTE's) and
not actual persons.  One FTE may be one person working 40 hours, two

lines of authority, hiring procedures, or staff training element is
included.  Standards for nonresidential  programs should be developed
that address these issues by establishing guidelines for service
providers in their development of clear personnel policies.
Regular training is essential to the viability of the entire
community care system and participation  in ongoing training programs
is included as a portion of each person's nondirect care responsibil-
ities.  In addition, time is allocated for staff meetings, client
conferences, record keeping, consultation, eduction, liaison with
other agencies, and travel.  It is assumed that most staff would spend
70% of their time in direct care tasks and only 30% in nondirect care
responsibilities.  The latter figure is significantly less than that
used by the National  Institute of Mental Health in computing similar
staffing requirements and is estimated to be somewhat less than that
presently being practiced in community mental health centers in the
Commonwealth.
Provided with each program model is a service analysis.  These
analyses quantify the work to be done by a program and the staff time
available for performing  it.  These and certain other statistics are
used to check the appropriateness of the programs' projected utilization,
direct and non-direct care staffing and unit costs.

I.  ASSESSMENT TEAM
The Assessment Team will provide a major coordinating, evaluation,
assessment and individual  treatment planning function for the 427 at risk
persons in each OMH area in Region I.  The Team will provide a core inter-
disciplinary staff and will draw upon professionals from the Medication,
Conmunity Service, Crisis Intervention, and Psychotherapy Programs to
provide an individual  interdisciplinary team for each client.  The
individual client's team will be responsible for drafting and annually
reviewing individual service plans for the client.  More frequent than
annual reviews may be requested by the community service coordinator,
may be planned by the client's team or may be required because of a
crisis incident.  The Team ideally should be based in a community mental
health center.
A.  Definition
A program designed to provide initial screening, assessment and
service planning for all at risk persons in the DMH service system
and to annually or more frequently review and update the initial
service plan.

II.  COMMUNITY SERVICE COORDINATION  PROGRAM
Community service coordinators should be closely related to the
Assessment Team which will serve as the intake point for at risk clients
in an Area.  They should be assigned after the Assessment Team screen-
ing and once it is determined that DMH services will be made available
to the client through an individual community service plan.  Each
service coordinator should have a caseload which reflects a range of
client difficulties since long term ability to constantly handle the
clients most disorganized and frequently in crisis is limited.
A.  Definition
Community  service coordination involves responsibility for
establishing a supportive human relationship with each client;
providing itermittent supportive'counseling with respect to
problems in daily living; coordinating, monitoring and initiating
changes in the agreed upon service plan for a client; providing
continuity for clients as they move through various services of
the system; and advocating for client vis a vis the mental health
and generic service systems.
8.  Program Elements
Program ^wi 11
1.  Work closely with Assessment Team to receive referrals
of clients for whom DMH services are being planned.
2.  Establish a primary support relationship with the client
through periodic individual meetings at a clinic location and
in the field (e.g., in a client's home, residential  program
or day program).
3.  Meet periodically with the program staff or individuals
providing services for the client to monitor client's progress
(131)

13
and services and to assure linkages and communication among
services when a client is receiving more than one service.
4.  Aid client's transition from one service or program to
another.
5.  Assist clients in meeting demands of community living,
including advocating for the client's needs with community
agencies and other service providers.
S.  Act as resource for referral and assistance of clients in
obtaining generic education, employment and recreation services.
m
7.  Arrange for periodic revaluations of client by the
Assessment Team and referral to other services when appropriate
or discharge planning and recommendations when appropriate.
8.  Receive consultations from the Assessment Team, Crisis
Unit, and Medication Unit.
9.  Casework supervisors will assist in staffing  individual
service planning teams drawn up by the Assessment Team and
will provide direct care two days per week.
C.  Clients
This program model will provide Community Service coordination
to 427 clients at any one time.  The caseload for an individual
community service worker- will he between 30 and 35 clients.
No worker will have more than 5 acute severely disturbed clients.
Clients are projected to need Community Service coordination
for 50 weeks annually.

III.  PSYCHOTHERAPY COUNSELING PROGRAM
Access  to  regular  psychotherapy,  in  addition  to  that  provided
through  DMH residential  or  day  programs, will  be provided  through
referral  by  the  Assessment  Team or  the  community  service  coordinator.
The therapists  will  work  closely  with  the  Assessment  Team and the
Community  Service  Coordination  Program and will  aid  in  staffing  indivi-
dual  service  planning  teams  structured  by  the  Assessment  Program.  Since
it  is  expected that  support  for  problems  of  daily  living  would be
offered  by  the  community  service  coordinators  and residential  or  day
program staff,  therapy  should  be considered  a supplementary  service
available  to  those  clients  where  day-to-day  supportive  help  is  not  suf-
ficient  and individual  therapy  is  recommended.
A.  Definition
Family and individual  psychotherapy  services will  provide
regular supportive therapy oriented  to short term needs and goals
of clients and families as a supplement to DMH residential or day
services, or as the sole service for some DMH clients.
B.  Program  Elements
Program will
1.  Recieve referrals of potential  clients from the
Assessment Team or Community  Service  Coordinator
as part of client's overall  service plan.
4
2.  Meet periodically  (ranging from several  times weekly
to once or twice a month) with the client and/or
family for one hour supportive  therapy  sessions
directed to short term needs and goals of client.
3.  Reoort to the Community  Service Coordinator  progress
or problems with  the client.

6.  Receive  consultation  from the Assessment Team,

Psychotherapy/counseling will be available for those clients
who require intense, specialized assistance in modifying behaviors
which they experience as problematic, resolving intrapsychic con-
flicts which interfere with their functioning and/or acquiring

interpersonal  relationships.  Therapy and counseling may be
individual, group, or family, depending on client needs.
This program model will serve 44 clients per area (10 per cent)
annually providing approximately one hour per week of psycho-
therapy for 50 weeks per year.  Each therapist would carry a

All clients in each Area will need an initial evaluation to

in close physical proximity to the Assessment Team.  Staff of this

staffing individual service planning teams for all at risk DMH clients

A.  Definition
A program designed to evaluate, in conjunction with the
Assessment Team, the need for medication for all at risk DMH
clients in the Area, to prescribe and monitor medication for
those clients who require it, and to provide supplementary home
nursing visits for those persons having physical health care
needs related to medication.

those requiring medication, determine aDpropriate

5.  Provide periodic home visits designed to deliver or

6.  Provide regular weekday coverage for determining
medication needs and administering medication for

VII.  CRISIS INTERVENTION  UNIT
This program will  respond to crises in homes, DMH residences or
day programs and will act as the intake point for all clients in
crisis.  It will work closely with the Assessment Team to initiate
revaluation of clients in crisis if they are already in the DMH
service system or to initiate an assessment and individual  service
plan if the client is new to the DMH service system.  The program will
receive referrals from a community service coordinator, a DMH con-
tracted program (day or residential), other public and private agencies,
the client or any citizen.  It will have the capacity to respond to a
crisis through visits to the client's home, bringing the client to a
clinic location or providing temporary residential  services in a small
residential  setting exclusively reserved for clients in crisis but
preferably operated by a nonprofit community agency which is also pro-
viding other residential  services for DMH.  In all cases there must be
adequate staff to be with, support and follow the client fhrough the
crisis for up to five days.  The Crisis Intervention Program will  receive
back up support from the Assessment Team.  For clients not capable of
returning to some residential  setting or their home after five days,
for highly assaultive persons, or those needing medical  attention,
voluntary or involuntary inpatient services in general hospitals will
have to be considered.
A.  Definition
A program designed to provide crisis intervention on a 24 hour
a day, 7 days a week basis for up to five days, 24 hours a day, to
clients both new to the DMH system and those already receiving DMH
services.

XI.  VOCATIONAL  REHABILITATION
Vocational services should, wherever possible, be utilized in the
community, rather than creating special programs for OMH clients.
Clients who do not require intensive supervision in Day Treatment or
Day Activity Programs would presumably be able to participate in a
CETA, WIN, NYC, OIC, or other privately financed job training program
with the supportive help of their family and/or residential  placement
counselor or their community service coordinators.  For those persons
needing additional support and assistance in locating employment, a
transitional employment and job placement program is necessary.  For
persons not yet capable of working in regular employment settings, a
prevocational and sheltered workshop program would be created.
While a number of vocational  rehabilitation services and program
models are being proposed, we realize that there are many other types
of programs that can and should be encouraged to develop-  The absence
of such programs from this model is not to imply that new, creative,
and innovative approaches to vocational rehabilitation should not be
encouraged.  Some specific models that are valuable for different
client ability levels and interests include client managed businesses,
outdoor work programs, and cottage industries.

XIII.  TRANSPORTATION
Transportation of clients to and from programs and appointments is
an ongoing problem for all mental health and social service providers.
Creating separate transportation systems, however, is not cost effective
or manageable, given the varying needs of clients and the fact that for
some clients transportation needs will  change periodically, and in some
cases, frequently.  For this reason transportation  should be included
in full time Day Activity, Day Treatment and Sheltered Workshop Programs.
In addition, most residential  programs will  find that staff have to
provide transportation  for clients' appointments or other special  needs,
as well as for social and recreational  group activities.  Funding for
these programs should include the purchase of a vehicle and ongoing
transportation costs.  Individual  transportation  to clinics, counseling,
jobs, higher education and non-DMH training for those not in DMH
residences would be arranged by the client with assistance from the
community  services coordinator if necessary.
(181)

63
XIV.  EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS
Educational needs of clients who require intensive DMH services
should be met in the context of Day Treatment and Day Activity
Programs.  Clients who are then able to move into adult education
programs or college courses should be encouraged and aided to do so.
All youth (age 22 and under) should receive CORE evaluations and be
provided services via their local board of education.  For adolescents,
these services should include a comprehensive day treatment/educational
program specifically designed to meet their needs as identified in
the CORE evaluation.  Pursuant to Chapter 766, it is the responsibility
of local school boards to implement such programs.

I.  INTRODUCTION
This document sets forth the number and type of residential
placements that must be designed and created for the mentally
disabled population in Region I.  Having drafted a general
description of 12 residential models, including staffing patterns
and costs (see Community Residential Alternatives), and having
grouped the disabled population into 22 clusters representing
different client needs (see Summary of Clusters for Northampton
State Hospital), it was then necessary to match each cluster
with a primary and, if appropriate, secondary placement recom-
mendation.  The conclusions of the matching process are set forth
in Part II.
While most clusters are assigned only one primary placement
recommendation, in certain cases several primary placement
recommendations are suggested.  Wherever an apartment placement
is recommended as a first choice, it is always coupled with a
group home or transitional community residence.  This reflects
the fact that both placements are programmatically  approximately
the same, and that the determination of which should be created
and funded is primarily an administrative choice best left to
the implementation phase of this planning process.  In certain
other cases two or more placements are suggested as first
choices with percentages assigned to each.  In these cases it
is recognized that the least restrictive alternative is most
desirable, but given the institutionalization of some persons
in that cluster, immediate placement in that alternative may not
be appropriate for all clients in that cluster.  It is clearly
intended, however, that such clients will be provided necessary
training and support as to enable them to move into the less
restrictive placement shown as soon as possible.  Secondary
placements are considered to be less desirable than the primary
placements for most clients; however, they are to be considered
as options for certain clients in clusters with documented
special needs.
The Summary of Clusters and the Analysis of the Mentally
Disabled Population (Appendix E) describe the number of persons ,
in each cluster for both the Hospital and community populations.
It should be noted that, pursuant to the precedental rules
described in the Summary of Clusters, adolescent, mentally retarded,
chronic, and acute clients with serious behavioral problems were
initially factored out and placed in the assaultive cluster (c).

A. • Acute Subpopulations
A significant portion of the thirty-two persons in this

residential crisis intervention program is appropriate and
has already been included in Part III, above.
Because a non-residential program does not have the
capability of responding to the security needs of highly
assaultive or committed persons, a limited number of general
hospital psychiatric beds will be necessary.  Given the
small number and rapid turnover of such cases, tw_en£.y

interesting to note that a detailed study of general
hospital resource allocations by the Western Massachusetts

I.  Introduction
The Department of Mental Health has the primary and ultimate
responsibility for creating and maintaining a comprehensive system
of community treatment and support programs appropriate to the needs
of mentally disabled persons.  This responsibility is undertaken on
a local level through Regional and Area Offices which develop, fund,
manage, coordinate, and monitor these programs.  To the extent that
services are delivered through many independent providers, the Depart-
ment's responsibilities can only be fulfilled If it has the manage-
ment capacity to oversee a diverse delivery system.  Moreover, given
the clinical advantages of providing much treatment and training out-
side of the residential environment, the task of ensuring that its
clients regularly receive appropriate services makes the Department's
management responsibilities especially complex.  The Regional and Area
Offices presently lack adequate mental health resources to fulfill those
responsibilities, since they are primarily geared to an institution
based service system.  In order to develop and manage quality community
programs, a management component must be included in the planning design.
Portions of this component like the direct care components, should be
purchased through contract mechanisms.  An outline of such a component,
vith a specific description of the organizational structure, is attached.
(203)

Page 2
II.  The Providers
It is expected that the actual provision of services will be done
chiefly through private nonprofit corporations experienced In design-
ing and implementing residential and non-residential programs for
mentally disabled persons.  The Department will contract with these
Independent providers pursuant to standard RFP procedures and reg-
ulations established by the Office of Administration and Finance.
It is estimated that there are on the average, 40 contracts per
area and 200 contracts regios-wide. in Region I, totalling roughly
$8 million dollars.  Implementation of this plan might double their
number and/or size.  This increase in Area and Regional responsibility
cannot be over emphasized.  Area and Regional Offices provide tech-
nical assistance to vendors in developing their proposals and monitor
contract operations In order to ensure that all programs are compliant
with State regulations and are an integral part of a comprehensive
system.  If an Area elects to become a primary service provider for
some of its clients, the management component must be modified
accordingly.  In certain cases, the Regional Office may also pro-
vide services for high risk/low incidence clients in inter-area
programs.  This should be reflected in Regional Office structure
and staffing.
(204)

Page 3
III.  General Description of Functions, Management Areas and Activities
Although Regional and Area Offices address very different levels
of operations, both must have the ability to perform two types of
functions:  planning and development and monitoring and coordination.
These functions must be performed in three management areas:  pro-
gram management, fiscal and personnel management, and information
management.  Table I shows the matrix of functions by management
areas and lists the major types of activities associated with each
combination of function and management area.  A general descrip-
tion of these activities follows which does not detail the dif-
ference between regional and area activities.  However in sections
17 and V Area and Regional Office activities are specified separately.
A.  Program Management
Within the program management area three activities re-
flect the planning and development funtion.  System and program develop-
ment refers to planning a community care system, including residen-
tial and non-residential programs and linkages to generic services.
This activity also includes developing vendors and agencies and pro-
viding technical assistance in drafting proposals.  Staff train-
ing and development involves insuring that adequately trained
manpower is available to meet program needs.  Community develop-
ment consists of working with citizen boards and councils to
facilitate community acceptance and client integration.  This is
done by educating citizens and developing local leadership.

Four activities are associated with the monitoring and coordination
function within program management.  System and program coordination in-
cludes developing functional linkages between programs, facilitating the
sharing of information when appropriate, supervising the transition of
services from institutions to communities and ensuring that clients con-
tinue to move through community programs towards less restricitve, more
independent living with appropriate continuity of care.  Legal services
differ from the area to the regional level.
At the regional level
legal services consist of legal counsel to the Regional and Area offices.
Program monitoring occurs primarily at the area level.  It involves over-
seeing the community care system.  This includes reviewing and approving
vendor contracts, ensuring contract compliance through periodic reviews
of programs and technical assistance in the implementation of "plans of
correction" in cases of non-compliance.  Prograa monitoring also includes
reviewing and resolving any complaints by clients or advocates against il
programs.1  Quality assurance is primarily a regional function although
Area Office staff will participate.  This activity involves annual re-
views of programs to assure compliance with program and professional
standards.  It is a crucial activity in setting the staff for program
monitoring.

B.  Fiscal and Personnel Management
there are four activities associated with the planning and
development function within the area of fiscal and personnel management.
Budget development and contracting refer to the process by which dollars
are assigned to accounts and vendors in compliance with state laws and re-
gulations.  Contract development can extend to assisting providers in
writing contracts.  Spending and revenue planning involves establishing
expenditure schedules and strategies for generating revenues so that
programs can operate uninterrupted by issues of fiscal solvency.
The monitoring and coordination function is reflected in three
activities in the fiscal and personnel management area. Expenditure and
revenue monitoring refer to tracking spending and revenues to ensure
compliance with spending and revenue plans.  A goal of such monitoring is
to uncover variances from plans while there is time to correct them.
Auditing involves monitoring contracts to ensure that vendors are oper-
ating in compliance with state fiscal regulations  and laws.  Personnel
management and affirmative action involves facilitating the recruitment,
hiring, development and maintenance of an appropriately skilled and
motivated workforce composed of minority employees to a degree consis-
tent with affirmative action guidelines.
C.  Information Management
In the information management area there are three planning
and development related functions.  Long range planning consists of the
development of explicit goals for clients and programs within a 3 to5
year planning horizon.  This goal setting is a key area of citizen in-
volvement.  (208)

Page 7
It is also a component reguixed in most federal grant proposals and
increasingly in state health and social service planning.  Annual planning
involves devising strategies for allocating dollars to programs.  These
plans are the basis for budget development.  Research for program develop-
ment includes needs assessment and evaluation research designed to
provide information as to what client needs are and what programs most
successfully meet them.  This information is necessary for deciding
what programs to develop, and/or fund,  it also provides back up for
federal grants, determination of need procedures, etc.
Finally, within the information management area two activities
relate to monitoring and coordination.  The first is developing and
maintaining client, personnel, fiscal and service management information
systems.  These systems information as to:  types and quantities of
services provided; numbers and types of clients served; staffing pat-
terns and activities; costs.  Such information is basic to most manage-
ment activities.  The second is program evaluation and research.  This
activity provides information as how well different services work for
different clients.  This information is the key to system and program
planning.
(209)

ATTACHMENT G
SURVEY OF EXISTING COMMUNITY
MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES
FINAL DRAFT
I.  Introduction
. The documents in Phase I of the planning process designed
a. range of residential and nonresidential program models and
determined the actual number of placements which must be created
in each of those models to meet the needs of the members of the
-plaintiff class.  The Summary of Principles and Conclusions of
; Phase I correlated all planning documents and estimated the total
I cost for creating and maintaining a system of community mental
health services for a specific portion of the plaintiff class
who were hospitalized in a given two year period (planning
population).  Given the fact that some of the programs needed
by the planning population already existed, although not necessarily
in a form comparable to the relevant model, it thus was necessary
to assess the capacity and adequacy of existing programs to serve
this planning population.  The resultant information could then
be used to determine the actual number of new residential and
nonresidential placements which must be created and the extent
to which existing programs must be upgraded to satisfy the
plaintiffs' needs as set forth in the Phase I planning documents.
(221)

II.  The Process
After extensive discussion of various assessment tech-
niques, a process was developed over several months to generate
and analyze relevant data on the capacity and adequacy of existing
programs.  It was recognized at the outset that even an extensive
research project using sophisticated computer methodologies
would not be significantly more reliable than information
gathered through individual interviews and analysis of existing
contracts due to the limits on the type and accessibility of
information maintained by community service providers.  Therefore,
a two step process was adopted which initially determined the
capacity of existing programs to serve members of the planning
population and which subsequently analyzed this data in light
of the program models to assess their adequacy.
The data gathering phase of this process began with a
review of all mental health programs funded in whole or in part
by. the Department of Mental Health.  Through a series of questions
addressed to each Area Director in separate interviews (see
Appendix A), the programs in each Area which significantly serve
members of the planning population were delineated and their
actual client capacity determined.  A list of all relevant pro-
grams, by Area, and their capacity to serve the planning population
was then compiled for review and certification by the Regional
Services Administrator.  It was recognized that this approach
not only provided a reliable measure of the extent of services
(222)

offered by existing programs to the most disabled population,
but also created a standard against which all programs and Area
managers could be held accountable in the future.
An adequacy assessment instrument to collect information
as to each program's personnel and fiscal resources was then
carefully drafted, discussed, and finalized (see Appendix B).
For each program determined to significantly serve the planning
population a separate staff and funding survey form was completed,
either by the 'Area Director based on a review of contracts and
other Department statistics or through a formal site visit to
the service provider by the Area Director, Regional Office
staff person, and a representative of the plaintiffs.  Using this
survey instrument, accurate information was generated as to the
staff and fiscal resources of existing community programs which
are available to deliver each of the model residential and non-
residential services described in the planning documents.
To summarize and analyze this data, two formats were
created (see Appendix C).  The first described all available
resources in Region I for each residential and nonresidential
service and then assessed the adequacy of existing programs
providing that service by comparing the available resources with
the standards set forth in the planning documents.  This compari-
son was done not only for present resources, but also for
anticipated program resources included in the new FY'79 budget,
as approved, and the FY'80 budget, as requested by che Department.
The second format compiled the adequacy conclusions for each
(223)

service and presented a composite description of the adequacy
of all existing residential and nonresidential services.  This
summary was again done for present resources, approved FY*79
programs, and requested FY'80 programs.  The resultant data
analysis, a summary of which is attached as Appendix D,
provides a clear picture of which program models exist in
Region I, and the capacity and adequacy of those programs to
serve members of the planning population.
III.  Conclusion
Based on the carefully devised process for gathering and
analyzing information with respect to the capacity and adequacy
of existing community programs, several conclusions emerge:
1.  There is no unused capacity in existing programs to
serve the present residents of the Hospital.  There-
fore, further census reduction in conformity with
the residential and nonresidential placement recom-
mendations set forth in the planning documents, can
only be accomplished through the creation of new pro-
grams or the expansion of existing programs to serve
these members of the planning population.
2.  There are several residential and nonresidential
programs which have the capacity to serve a specific
portion of the planning population but which are
inadequate, as compared to the planning documents,
(224)

to meet the needs of the members of the planning
population living in the community who participate
in these programs.  The projected cost of upgrading
these programs for community clients is $2,801,506.
3.  There are other residential and nonresidential programs
which are entirely absent or only minimally avail-
able in most Areas in Region I, and which therefore
must be newly created to serve the members of the
planning population living in the community who need
such programs. The projected cost of creating or
expanding these programs for community clients is
$3,812,077.
Thus these conclusions indicate that the residential and
nonresidential programs which now exist in Region I are sub-
stantially inadequate to serve the 1755 members of the planning
population not presently institutionalized at the Northampton
State Hospital.  The total cost of upgrading these programs to
provide adequate treatment in appropriate less restrictive
alternatives for these persons is $6,613,583.  Some but not all
of these costs include federal reimbursements under Titles XIX
and XX of the Social Security Act, which would be significant
for many nonresidential programs.
Therefore, in order to reduce 607. of this inadequacy in
existing programs during FY'80, it will require $2,933,421
during that year (see Appendix E).  A significant portion of
(225)

this cost ($1,404,341) is already included in and has been
approved as part of the Region I budget request for FY'80.
To eliminate the remaining inadequacy during FY'8l, it will
cost $1,772,440 during that year.
(226)

applications;

cerns of Hospital employees;

trative procedures which may be found to unduly delay reimburse-
ment to service providers and vendors or which may be, found to
unnecessarily limit administrative flexibility; and
8.  Working cooperatively with persons, agencies,
departments, programs, or organizations not a party, to this
Decree and not within the direct or indirect control of the
defendants to insure full compliance with the provisions of
this Decree.

documents.text:
Brewster v. Commw. of Mass
•HIIllI
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
DISTRICT OF MASSACHUSETTS
DAVID BREWSTER, etal.,  )
Plaintiffs  )
)
v.  )  CIVIL ACTION NO. 76-4423-F
)
MICHAEL S. DUKAKIS, et al.,)
Defendants  )
FINDINGS AND ORDER
March 19, 1981
FREEDMAN, D.J.
Based on the hearing held on March 16, 1981, this
Court makes the following findings:
1.  The defendants have failed to comply with
Paragraphs 24 and 47 of the Consent Decree entered in this
matter, due to their failure to take effective measures to
secure timely release of funds for programs required by the
Decree.  The absence of effective coordination among the
defendants in assembling documentation required by the legis-
lature has resulted in substantial delays in release of funds
held in certain legislative supplementary accounts and
targeted for Consent Decree programs.
2.  The efforts made by the defendants to access these
funds were drastically complicated by vague and unnecessarily
restrictive language imposed by legislative committees
limiting access to Consent Decree supplementary accounts.
3.  Although staff members connected with the House
Ways and Means Committee were requested, by Order of this
Court, to attend the hearing to provide the Court with necessary
information regarding the processes of the House Ways and Means
Committee, no representative staff members for that Committee
appeared.  Staff members and counsel from the Senate Ways
and Means Committee did appear.
n

4.  The delays in coordinating submission of docu-
mentation to the legislature by the defendants resulted in
late release of funds contained in the 5 OJ. 1^9.006 account,
earmarked for improvement in the existing community mental
health system and specifically required by Paragraph 19 of the
Decree.  As a result of delays in release of funds from this
account, members of the plaintiff class were unnecessarily
hospitalized and denied their right to placement in less
restrictive community settings, as required by the Decree.
5.  As a result of the lack of coordination by the
defendants, and the unnecessarily restrictive language imposed
by the legislature limiting access, approximately $2.6 million
contained in the 5100-0101 supplementary account is currently
being withheld from the community mental health system.
6.  Without these funds, the local Department of
Mental Health administrators will be unable to pay community
mental health providers through the end of this fiscal year.
In addition, a number of providers with short funded contracts,
or with personnel transferred from state slots to contract
positions, will begin running out of money as early as April
30,  1981.
7.  The plan proposed by the defendant Executive
Office of Human Services to avoid the destructive ramifications
of the failure to obtain release of the 5100-0101 funds is
wholly inadequate to prevent harm to the plaintiff class.  The
use of so-called reversions from one account to absorb shortages
in another account requires a protracted process of contract
amendment, negotiation with and active cooperation from private
mental health agencies and processing of dozens of such amend-
ments through the elaborate state bureaucracy.  Representatives
of several agencies whose cooperation would be critical to the
amendment process necessary to generate reversions indicated
an unwillingness to be involved in this process.  Dependency
- 2 -

on reversions for program funding has, in addition, caused
considerable delay and harm to members of the plaintiff class
when used in the past.  Finally, the use of the reversion
process will not generate sufficient funds to offset existing
shortages.
8.  The defendants have violated Paragraph 20 of
the Consent Decree, and the subsequent agreed upon recommenda-
tions of the Monitor to implement this Paragraph, by failing
to approve in a timely manner contracts for several mentally
retarded persons currently at Northampton State Hospital and
to be served by the Franklin/Hampshire Area Office of Region
One of the Department of Mental Health.
9.  The delays in accessing funds from the 5011-9006
account intended to upgrade existing community programs and
create necessary new programmatic services may without
prompt action result in an inability by the Department of
Mental Health to spend these monies in an effective, timely
and positive manner.
10.  The additional requirements for numerous adminis-
trative reports both to the legislature and to the Central
Office of the Department of Mental Health has placed demands
on the Office of Region One of the Department of Mental Health
that cannot be met by current personnel resources without harm
to members of the plaintiff class.  Reporting requirements are
forcing regional administrative personnel to abbreviate their
programmatic efforts.
Based on the preceding findings of fact, the Court
hereby ORDERS:
1.  That the defendants submit no later than April
17,  1981 a plan for productive and effective expenditure of
all funds contained in the 5011-9006 account, assuring that
no portion of these funds is reverted tojthe^ general funds but
is invested effectively in improving existing community mental
- 3 -

health services as required by Paragraph 19 of theJDecree.
2.  That the defendants submit to this Court no
later than July 31, 1981 an accounting specifying details
regarding all expenditures out of the 5011-9006 account.
3.  That the defendants take all action legally
permitted to insure retroactive payment to private contract
agencies who have incurred expenses for members of the plaintiff
class subject to reimbursement from the 5011-9006 account.
4.  That the defendants, no later than April 3, 1981,
approve all contracts submitted prior to the date of this
Order for programs to serve members of the plaintiff class
in Region One of the Department of Mental Health,  or .report
v
to the Court in writing as to each contract not approved
the legal or administrative reasons which require denial of
approval.
5.  That the defendants submit to the Court in writing
no later than April 10, 1981 a plan for increasing the adminis-
trative staff of Region One of the Department of Mental Health
to carry out the reporting and statistical demands of the legis-
lature and the Central Office of the Department of Mental Health,
to insure that no member of the plaintiff class is harmed by
^draining of resources away from program development.
6.  That the defendants are hereby enjoined forthwith
from employing contract reversions to make up for funding
shortages caused by their failure to obtain timely release of
funds in the 5100-0101 supplementary budget account.
7.  That the defendants, no later than April 10, 1981,
resubmit a request to the appropriate legislative committees
for release of the necessary funds from the 5100-0101 account.
The defendants will, prior to that date, meet with the legis-
lative committees and ascertain precisely what documentation is
required by the committees to obtain release of these funds.
The defendants will further communicate to the legislature the
- 4 -

findings of this Court related to the effect of the vague
and restrictive language attached to this account and the Order
of this Court preventing use by the defendants of any reversions
to make up for funding shortages caused by the failure to re-
lease funds from the 5100-0101 account.  The defendants will
further communicate to the legislative committees the willing-
ness of this Court, and of this Court's appointed Monitor, to
assure the legislative committees of oversight and accounting
requirements to prevent any waste of released funds.
8.  That the defendants, no later than fourteen  (14)
days after release of funds from the 5100-0101 account, submit
to this Court a written plan specifying all expected expendi-
tures to be made from this account.  The defendants will also
provide this Court, no later than July 31, 1981, with an
accounting of all expenditures made from this account.
All until further Order of this Court.
United States District Judge
